comments.text:
Yeah. I'd buy this tech if it's from some other company than Google or 
Apple (doesn't matter much which other company) and if the price was okay 
(I'd pay 150 at most). Other than that, no thank you. And even if I had one 
by some other company, I wouldn't wear it all the time, just when it would 
come in handy like laying in bed or something like that.
comments.author: LightningMotionshot

comments.text:
+432neptune If I take a picture with my phone, it gets uploaded to OneDrive 
automatically (and I'm not even using Windows Phone). So no, it's not 
always manual, sometimes uploads are automatic.
comments.author: LightningMotionshot

comments.text:
+Jason Morley Why would you upload it to the cloud unless you wanted to? 
You don't need to unless you want to.
comments.author: 432neptune

comments.text:
+432neptune Okay, question. What if the recording of a person with Google 
Glass didn't go up to "the cloud", but instead could go directly to your 
personal desktop PC at home, or a specialised private server? That way, 
that data is yours, not something the NSA can walk into Google and ask for.

And if a person is oppressed or assaulted, that data could be released by 
the person to be used to find the oppressor or assaulted. And if they felt 
it truly important, they could share it publicly for the whole world to see.

And that, to me, is the potential of these devices: directly empowering 
people, empowering the public to make acts of oppression and violence 
known, to act against oppression.

There's a reason the first step of a tyrannical regime when things go south 
is to try and shut down twitter: Free exchange and easy communication is 
the death of tyranny.
comments.author: Jason Morley

comments.text:
+spinemelter2000 But it still doesn't invade your privacy, it's just a 
smartphone of sorts that you can use without Internet or anything like 
that. 

And it doesn't record anything without your permission, since it's easy to 
realize that something is being recorded. 

Besides, any and all info that a company has on people must be deliverd to 
the NSA. But who cares? The NSA doesn't, that's for sure. They'd only look 
at your stuff if you're suspected of something illegal.
comments.author: 432neptune

comments.text:
Google and Facebook are much more efficient at eroding our privacy rights 
than any government, real or fictional. Google Glasses and Google contact 
lenses are beyond anything the NSA agents could ever dream of.
comments.author: spinemelter2000

comments.text: It doesn't do any of those things.
comments.author: 432neptune

comments.text:
Orwellian is when the power is in the hands of a centralised authority, 
such as the government. Technology like this can easily and arguably does 
put the power straight into the hands of the people, in many ways it could 
be argued to be the opposite of Orwellian: Technology that can empower the 
masses, and not the oppressors of the masses.
comments.author: Jason Morley

+i is penguin Proof or it didn't happen.

Also I wouldn't be goad about it. I'm not an idiot, even I know further 
intrusion of technology into our daily lives is inevitable. Nobody can 
predict the future, but obviously new technologies are redefining all 
aspects of life (look at this very youtube channel, and other big youtube 
channels, and youtube in general; if it's not replacing tv, then it's at 
least a new type of mass medium existing alongside tv; it's a new way of 
entertaining, but for many people it's also new way of working), and it's 
crucial that before embracing all of these new developments, we should 
think of the consequences, and the things we are willing to give up in 
favor of new technologies and thus ever more (work)efficiency, so we can 
make the right choices and think of ways to avoid negative effects on our 
society.

comments.text:
How would that be possible? The whole point is that the screen can form 
because there's a certain distance between your eyes and the glasses. 
Lenses are in direct contact with your eyes, and there would be 
difficulties with the sound. Also I'd imagine there would be some health 
problems with using them. Like computerscreens today, you are focusing your 
eyes on one spot in space for a longer period of time, which is very 
straining. Also, do we need all of this stuff? I'll admit that this is 
pretty remarkable, but aren't there other problems that require innovative 
technical solutions? Call me someone who idealises the past, but I don't 
see how certain developments are that beneficial to humankind at all.
